comments.commentBody: Wondering what Canada does for ballast with no pennies around.

Hi Leapy
I've been enjoying your posts on Rex's site.
We are using nickels for ballast in Canada now!
WVC
Aha!  That must be why I keep seeing Canadian pennies turn up in my change!

I am sorry to say Ms. Gorski that this puzzle does not work in Canada-we did away with pennies/cents years ago!
Other than that very, very clever.
Regards to all from B.C.

WVC
nice to see you comment on a sunday puzzle Howie!

I do not like the term
"passed away." I
prefer "died" -- people
do not PASS ANYWHERE.
Nonsense like this is why I plan on having my body cremated.

The fact that they don't mind doesn't mean that there's no such thing as treating them disrespectfully, or that it's OK.  If people told vicious lies about the deceased, the deceased wouldn't mind, but that wouldn't make it OK.  Ms. Burbank's family creates a scene, a kind of diorama, and uses her body as a prop in it.  I am astonished that anyone would think they have the right to do that without her consent.  In my view, they have the duty to bury or cremate it with dignity.  Even if it helps them with their loss, who are they to take this woman's body and make a spectacle of it?

So many people uncomfortable with death! We are a death-denying society.
I was trotted to granny's open casket when I was 6 & told to kiss her & hold her hand. Then uncles, aunts, cousins...
If someone wants to be posed it's their choice. Points for creativity. It likely helps survivors cope with their loss. Who are we to judge. Disrespect for the deceased? They likely don't mind a whit right now.
When did we become so narrow minded?
Never hurts to think differently about things.

More than 30 years later,  I have never forgotten the smile on the face of the  middle aged fellow seated in a chair, bedecked with flowers, being carried, surrounded by the typical revelers,  to his final fire in south India.
These look like scenes from Madame Tussaud's. I've never been a fan. Not a fan of the traditional embalmed body on view in a garish casket, either.

For those who like to plan their wakes and prefer to show their dead bodies in live activities--why not make a hologram of themselves in one of those favorite poses when alive? The three dimensional hologram can be shown in their wake to great effect while letting their cadavers rest in peace.

"Grieve and move on."

This is _how_ some people grieve and move on.
Hey, don't bring Florida into this. I was relieved to see we were conspicuously absent from the article. (Hiarious, by the way. Thanks for the chuckle.)
Oh, Miss Ley, you have made my day!  Brilliant, thank you so much!  I've been laughing for 20 minutes!

'Mummy, where is Daddy?  You told me he would be back for my 9th birthday tomorrow, and he promised last time I stayed with him in Florida that he would bring me a puppy'.  'Darling, your father is just fine and we were planning to surprise you because he has already arrived and is staying at an hotel a few blocks away, the newest in town called 'Morticia'. We'll all have dinner together and a cake there too.  I was just about to tell you to get dressed and brush your hair because he is expecting us to come over now, and we'll have a little party'.  'Cool, mom, I'm so happy and did he bring the puppy too?  'Yes, I already know that little Skip is in a box on your daddy's lap with a big red bow, but pretend to be surprised because it was meant to be a secret.'  'Mummy, I just love you and Daddy, and this is going to be the very, very best birthday ever, and I know that I will remember it all my life!  Mummy, why are you're crying!  You should be happy for me.  Let's go celebrate now with Daddy after I put on my new sweater with the Red Sox.  He'll like that, and I can't wait to see my new friend Skip too!'
I've heard that story, too, and have been told by LA friends that it's true!  I hope it is!

There was a film in the 70s (WC and Me) where W.C. Fields and his drinking buddies played a joke on Errol Flynn by having their deceased pal, John Barrymore, propped up at a card table with a drink in his hand. Probably a Hollywood myth but a pretty amusing scene.
Funny and the best laugh of the day.  Thanks!

A bit strange, perhaps, but looking at the photo of the deceased lady with some of her favourite props, I couldn't help but wonder if maybe the next big trend will be funerals in which the decedent poses with the causes (or at least contributory factors) of her or his demise. In any case, that movie 'A Weekend at Bernie's' couldn't help but come to mind. I can only hope that saying this won't bring the blokes with the butterfly nets to my door.

Well, all this is not an original idea. Auntie Mame is most likely still propped up in her armchair in a family attic where she spent most of her life as an old maid, knitting for her little nieces and nephews. And at last news, Norman Bates is still caring for his mother in her rocking chair.

A favorite story on the side, a true one, is an elderly man who was found after a year by the police. sitting upright in front of his old static T.V. looking in no pain if slightly mummified. For some reason, his neighbors took awhile to notice that the accumulation of mail in front of his door were about to be deemed a safety hazard by the Coop Board in the housing unit where he lived.

If they are sending that message, which I think is plausible, what a bizarre and, it seems to me, disrespectful thing to do--if people are attending that wake who are not in the family but are paying their respects.  If I understand you correctly, you're saying that the family is making some comment on the way she lived her life, perhaps one of anger and criticism.  Why should they air their dirty laundry in front of everybody else?  Why is that appropriate here?  The occasion should be about beginning the process of healing and moving on.
Have you read the article? It's the dead people themselves that have asked to be shown this or that way in their wakes, like with a glass of champagne and a cigarrette. No disrespect.

I agree that stuffing and mounting the dogs and cats is pretty weird.  But doing this to the remains of human beings is no more weird only if their moral status, and what we owe to them, is the same as for pets.
I guess it's no more weird than the people who have their dead dogs and cats stuffed and mounted; that's pretty weird too.
Thank you! I came back to this article specifically to read the comments. As a fellow New Orlenian, I've been wondering what these folks would say about a second line as well.

New Orleans has always been known for putting the 'fun' in funeral.   I have a feeling that many of the Times readers would find a traditional second line memorial to be fairly distasteful.  On paper, the concept of a second line sounds crass. In reality, though, when it's done properly it's a beautiful thing,  fun and tender and profound.  So perhaps a "seated funeral" has something to offer as a way of memorializing a loved one that we don't see when reading an article. I'm reserving judgement until I get invited to my first "seated funeral". Seeing as there have only been three so far in New Orleans, it's likely to be a long wait.

pfon71361, The thing is, it is not a high point in one's life when one's dead body is propped up together with a beer can, cigarette, etc., to create a kind of tableau.  Remembering our loved ones in the best possible way, it seems to me, means remembering times of significance, shared occasions, or achievement.  I don't see how this is showing respect at all.

Although not necessary, I wish to elaborate. The "hovering, competitive" behavior I mention caused me to eventually lose respect for my Dad. It seemed pathetic to me. It continued for years, throughout my teens and college years, his always doing things "better" than me and then looking for attention and appreciation. Then I just shut down and cut him out. I hope you son does not feel this way. While you may think you are "helping" him, I'm not sure he agrees. It may easily backfire. Your son deserves center stage, not you. I think he might prefer you backing him, rather than promoting your agenda and credentials. I do hope it gets better for you.

Creeps me out, but to each their own.  The first thing that always struck me at an open casket funeral or a beforehand viewing is how completely gone the real person is -- the train left the station, the soul went somewhere else.  All we are left with is a dead body and I, for one, don't really want to see him or her posed in everyday situations.  My opinion, of course.
The scene with Ms. Burbank is a representation, whereas an open casket is not.

The reviewer has seen other Clint Eastwood directed movies, right?

This is not unchartered territory for him, the reviewer needs to go and review Mr. Eastwood's oeuvre and find that American music is a theme, she should try to view "Bird".

The Export-Import bank also provides funds to companies who want to relocate American manufacturing facilities overseas.  The American taxpayer should not be forced to subsidize this type of operation.  If someone wants to finance the start-up of an import business, or if someone wants help in making sales of American produced goods overseas, I'm all for that.  If the outsourcing loophole can be tightened up, then I don't think anyone would have a problem about re-authorizing the agency.  Unfortunately, Tea Party Republicans are much better at complaining about problems than they are about enacting legislation to fix problems.

Ha!  When I moved to the Washington area in 1974, my native Washingtonian friends advised that under Mr. Marshall, the Redskins colors were burgundy, red, and caucasian!  However, ask any native (Washingtonian) if they remember Larry Brown's number.
Yeah, it's just a highly consequential blown call.

Well, I guess this answers "Achilles", in Texas, who asked a few days ago, "Beating Ghana 2-1 is big deal?" And, for good measure, "Socrates", in Verona, N.J., who proclaimed that "Ghana couldn't score against the broad side of a barn." Ghana also offered a pretty fair rejoinder to "RS", in Houston, who had concluded, "There is simply no way Ghana will beat Germany." As it turned out, they very nearly did, don'tcha think?!

The point is not that people shouldn't express strong opinions in this forum. But we sure see a lot of emphatic pontificating here that is very quickly shown to have been, at best, based on wholly inadequate evidence. Maybe there's just something about soccer that inspires some folks to believe that results are written in stone before the matches are ever played.

— Brian
